Hickman Price, Jr. Papers, 1918-1968

Finding aid prepared by:
Nika J. Kayne

did.abstract: Executive with the Kaiser-Frazer Corp., later with Willys Motor Inc. Corporate correspondence, including files concerning his work with Willys-Overland in Brazil; also materials relating to his interest in Latin America, including summary reports prepared for President-elect Kennedy in 1960; miscellaneous correspondence with Adlai Stevenson; and photographs.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The collection was donated by Hickman Price, Jr. (donor no. 4711) in 1975.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., Hickman Price, Jr. Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Hickman Price, Jr. was born on August 14, 1911, in Nashville, Tennessee. He attended Taft School, Philips Exeter Academy, and Columbia University. From 1932 to 1934, he assisted his father as a young man farming wheat in the Texas Panhandle; he then moved on to become a member of the Bankers Trust Company in New York City. After leaving here in 1941, he was appointed chief of the American Economic Mission to the Belgian Congo. Upon returning in 1945, Price was named executive assistant to the president, Graham-Paige Motors Corp. From 1945 to 1952, he was vice president and director of the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation in Willow Run, Michigan. In 1952, Price became president and director of Willys Overland Export Corp., and Willys Overland of Canada, Ltd. In 1954, he was named to be vice president of Willys Motors Inc.

Hickman Price Jr. was a notable figure in the post-war automotive industry. Because of his leadership position with Kaiser-Frazer and Willys Overland, Price helped shape the character of the overseas car market. Widely respected as a businessman, Price was also an influential social and political figure. He was an active Democrat and a staunch supporter of Governor G. Mennen Williams of Michigan and of the presidential aspirations of Adlai Stevenson and John F. Kennedy. Often consulted on matters of relations between the United States and Brazil, Price shared his expertise with members of the Kennedy administration. He further served his country with his appointment as Assistant Secretary of Commerce, a position he held from 1961 to 1963.

scopecontent.p: The papers of Hickman Price, Jr. document the workings of Willys Overland, Inc. and Kaiser-Frazer Corp, the two corporations which merged in 1953 and which became the principal international producers of the Jeep. Because so much of Price's career was spent in the development of the South American market, the collection includes much information about the role of American businesses in less well-developed economies. The collection is only partially processed.

Personal Materials consists of various family papers, speeches, reports, and financial information. Especially interesting among these materials are several letters addressed to Price from his father, Hickman Price, a prominent agriculturalist.

did.unittitle: Speech entitled, "A Look Ahead in Agriculture" delivered at annual convention of the Farm Equipment Manufacturers 1930
Papers concerning agricultural inspection tour of the Soviet Union 1931-1932
Memorandum on German Companies prepared for Bankers Trust Co. 1934
Reports prepared for the Bankers Trust Co. 1938, 1940

scopecontent.p: The bulk of the collection relates to Price's activities as an executive with the Kaiser-Frazer Corporation. Most of this consists of outgoing correspondence, 1945-1956. Although much of this is fairly typical office correspondence, it does provide some indication of the daily routine of a high-level automobile executive.

The Correspondence series (1949-1960; 1 linear ft.) consists of letters dealing with business affairs, and social and personal affairs of Hickman Price, Jr. Included here is Price's correspondence as Assistant Secretary of Commerce, family correspondence, and social communications with business and political figures. The bulk of the correspondence relates to the business of Willys Overland and Kaiser-Frazer. This includes correspondence with suppliers and distributors, personnel, foreign branch offices, and domestic divisions within the corporation. A sizeable amount of the correspondence is in Portuguese, but the bulk is in English.

odd.p: (Includes information about Price's biography of his grandfather as submitted to The National Cyclopedia of American Biography)
(Correspondence relating to the merger of Kaiser-Frazer and Willys Overland)
(Contains administrative and legal documents concerning the expansion of Willys Overland of Brazil; and procedures for obtaining the Douglas Long Beach Plant)

scopecontent.p: The Administrative series (1947-1956; .5 linear ft.) consists of records and minutes of various departmental divisions within Willys Overland and Kaiser-Frazer; official reports and policies and goals of the corporation; lists of cable codes designed to insure privacy in cabled messages; mailing lists; legal documents; and some organizational charts. The reports are especially interesting in that they portray the extent to which Willys Overland was involved in international economic and political affairs. Most of these reports were written by Price, and his predecessor Marcel DeMuller.

did.unittitle: Export Policy and Service, Willys Overland 1946-1952
Speech on the Geneva Conference, New York Times Export Issue 1947
"Address At The Opening of the U.S.A. Exhibit in Rio," 1963
"Background Notes and Suggestions of Policy on Latin America," 1960
re United States cooperation on Brazilian economic life 1959

scopecontent.p: The Financial series (1945-1967; .5 linear ft.) is divided into two subseries: corporate and personal. The corporate subseries documents some of the financial affairs of Willys Overland and Kaiser-Frazer. Included are account books, budgetary information, and financial statements. This subseries is valuable for its financial overview of the two companies in the period from 1945 to 1952. To be found in these files are annual expenditures, product prices, and other figures that reflect typical transactions. The second subseries included here deals with personal finances and consists of personal receipts, tax information, and stocks and securities of Price and his family.

Printed And Published Information (1947-1959; .5 linear ft.) consists in part of advertisements for the products of the Willys Overland and Kaiser-Frazer companies. This series documents the public face of a car company and the strategy it used to sell its product. Other materials in this series include magazines, pamphlets, product description brochures, and other materials published by Willys Overland advertising their products and outlining their ongoing activities.

odd.p: (Contains a number of newspaper clippings, mostly from Brazilian papers, in Portuguese)

did.unittitle: Technical Specifications, Jeep Commercial and Truck Chassis 1947

odd.p: (newspaper clippings from the Sao Paulo paper in Brazil, in Portuguese)
(includes congratulatory and laudatory letters addressed to Mr. Price at the conclusion of his post)

scopecontent.p: The last series, Photographs (1950-1960; .5 linear ft.) consists of photographs of Hickman Price, Jr. and his business associates in many different countries, but especially in South America. Also to be found here are photos of Marcel DeMuller, the previous president of Willys Overland. Many vehicles produced by Willys Overland and Kaiser-Frazer are also documented here. The photographs are divided into six topical categories: DeMuller, Marcel; Family photos and portraits; Hickman Price, Jr. and Business Associates; Margaret Bayne Price; Production and Manufacture; and Vehicles.

odd.p: (Previous president and general manager of Willys Overland, killed in 1952)
(Includes photos of Price, Mrs. Price, and their two sons)

did.unittitle: Hickman Price, Jr. and Business Associates

odd.p: (Various pictures of Price with other businessmen, in both large and small groups, mostly South American)
(Photos of Mrs. Price receiving an award at South American ceremony; newspaper article attached, in Portuguese)
(Documents various stages of the production and manufacture of the Willys Overland vehicles)
